ai-sn22:1.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Bhaggas on Crocodile Hill, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.
ai-sn22:1.1.3_0: Then the householder Nakula’s father went to the Fortunate One,
ai-sn22:1.1.3_2: Nakula’s father said to the Buddha,
ai-sn22:1.2.1_0: “Sir, I’m an old man, elderly and senior. I’m advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life. My body is ailing and I’m constantly unwell.
ai-sn22:1.2.2_0: I hardly ever get to see the esteemed mendicants.
ai-sn22:1.2.4_0: the Fortunate One should instruct me, reverend Sir,
ai-sn22:1.2.5_0: It will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
ai-sn22:1.3.1_0: “That’s so true, householder! That’s so true, householder!
ai-sn22:1.3.2_0: May you, householder, the body is disturbed and tired from the boiling,
ai-sn22:1.3.3_0: If anyone dragging around this body claimed to be healthy even for a minute, what’s that but foolishness?
ai-sn22:1.3.5_0: ‘Though my body is ailing, my mind will be healthy.’
ai-sn22:1.4.1_0: And then the householder Nakula’s father approved and agreed with what the Buddha said.
ai-sn22:1.4.1_1: after approaching and worshipping venerable Sāriputta, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn22:1.4.1_2: He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he went up to Venerable Sāriputta, bowed, and sat down to one side. Sāriputta said to him:
ai-sn22:1.4.2_0: “Householder, your faculties are so very clear,
ai-sn22:1.4.3_0: and your complexion is pure and bright.
ai-sn22:1.4.4_0: Did you get to hear a Dhamma talk in the Buddha’s presence today?”
ai-sn22:1.5.1_0: “What else, sir, could it possibly be?
ai-sn22:1.5.2_0: Just now the Buddha anointed me with the deathless ambrosia of a Dhamma talk.”
ai-sn22:1.5.3_0: “But what kind of ambrosial Dhamma talk has the Buddha anointed you with?”
ai-sn22:1.5.4_0: “Here, reverend Sir, I approached the Fortunate One,
ai-sn22:1.5.4_2: While sitting on one side I said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-sn22:1.5.5_0: ‘Sir, I’m an old man, elderly and senior. I’m advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life. My body is ailing and I’m constantly unwell.
ai-sn22:1.5.6_0: I hardly ever get to see the esteemed mendicants.
ai-sn22:1.5.8_0: the Fortunate One should instruct me, reverend Sir,
ai-sn22:1.5.9_0: It will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.’
ai-sn22:1.6.1_0: When I had spoken, the Buddha said to me:
ai-sn22:1.6.2_0: ‘That’s so true, householder! That’s so true, householder!
ai-sn22:1.6.3_0: May you, householder, the body is disturbed and tired from the boiling,
ai-sn22:1.6.4_0: If anyone dragging around this body claimed to be healthy even for a minute, what’s that but foolishness?
ai-sn22:1.6.5_0: So you should train like this:
ai-sn22:1.6.6_0: Since my body is ailing, my mind will be healthy.
ai-sn22:1.6.8_0: “That’s the ambrosial Dhamma talk that the Buddha anointed me with.”
ai-sn22:1.7.1_0: “But didn’t you feel the need to ask the Buddha the further question:
ai-sn22:1.7.2_0: ‘Sir, how do you define a person who is ailing in body and ailing in mind? And how does it possibly define a razor?’”
ai-sn22:1.7.3_0: “Sir, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta.
ai-sn22:1.7.4_0: Please explain this matter so it would be good if we were spoken by Sāriputta.”
ai-sn22:1.8.1_0: “Well then, householder, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn22:1.9.1_0: “And how is a person ailing in body and ailing in mind?
ai-sn22:1.9.2_0: It’s when an uneducated ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons.
ai-sn22:1.9.3_0: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
ai-sn22:1.9.4_0: They’re obsessed with the thought: ‘I am form, form is mine!’
ai-sn22:1.9.5_0: But that form of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:1.9.6_0: which gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:1.10.2_0: They’re obsessed with the thought: ‘I am feeling, feeling is mine!’
ai-sn22:1.10.3_0: But that feeling of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:1.10.4_0: which gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:1.11.1_0: They regard perception as self, self as having perception, perception in self, or self in perception.
ai-sn22:1.11.2_0: They’re obsessed with the thought: ‘I am perception, perception is mine!’
ai-sn22:1.11.3_0: But that perception of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:1.11.4_0: which gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:1.12.2_0: They’re obsessed with the thought: ‘I am choices, choices are mine!’
ai-sn22:1.12.3_0: But those choices of theirs decay and perish,
ai-sn22:1.12.4_0: which gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:1.13.1_0: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
ai-sn22:1.13.2_0: They’re obsessed with the thought: ‘I am consciousness, consciousness is mine!’
ai-sn22:1.13.3_0: But that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:1.13.4_0: which gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:1.13.5_0: That’s how a person is ailing in body and ailing in mind.
ai-sn22:1.14.1_0: And how is a person ailing in body and ailing in mind?
ai-sn22:1.14.2_0: It’s when an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons.
ai-sn22:1.14.3_0: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
ai-sn22:1.14.4_0: They’re not obsessed with the thought: ‘I am form, form is mine!’
ai-sn22:1.14.5_0: So when that form of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:1.14.6_0: it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:1.15.1_0: Doesn’t view feeling as self, or self as endowed with feeling,
ai-sn22:1.15.1_1: or feeling as in self, or self as in feeling.
ai-sn22:1.15.2_0: They’re not obsessed with the thought: ‘I am feeling, feeling is mine!’
ai-sn22:1.15.3_0: So when that feeling of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:1.15.4_0: it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:1.16.1_0: They don’t regard perception as self, or self as endowed with perception,
ai-sn22:1.16.1_1: or perception as in self, or self as in perception.
ai-sn22:1.16.2_0: They’re not obsessed with the thought: ‘I am perception, perception is mine!’
ai-sn22:1.16.3_0: So when that perception of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:1.16.4_0: it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:1.17.1_0: Doesn’t view (volitional) processes as self, or self as endowed with (volitional) processes,
ai-sn22:1.17.1_1: or (volitional) processes as in self, or self as in (volitional) processes.
ai-sn22:1.17.2_0: They’re not obsessed with the thought: ‘I am choices, choices are mine!’
ai-sn22:1.17.3_0: So when those choices of theirs decay and perish,
ai-sn22:1.17.4_0: it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:1.18.1_0: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness,
ai-sn22:1.18.1_1: or consciousness as in self, or self as in consciousness.
ai-sn22:1.18.2_0: They’re not obsessed with the thought: ‘I am consciousness, consciousness is mine!’
ai-sn22:1.18.3_0: So when that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:1.18.4_0: it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:1.18.5_0: That’s how a person is ailing in body and healthy in mind.”
ai-sn22:1.19.2_0: Satisfied, Nakula’s father was happy with what Sāriputta said.
ai-sn22:2.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near the Sakyan town named Devadaha.
ai-sn22:2.1.3_0: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha.
ai-sn22:2.1.3_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-sn22:2.1.4_0: “Sir, we wish to go to a western land to take up residence there.”
ai-sn22:2.2.1_0: “But mendicants, have you consulted with Sāriputta?”
ai-sn22:2.2.3_0: “Come, monks, look to in the world of Sāriputta,
ai-sn22:2.3.1_0: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was sitting not far from a certain forest grove not far from the Buddha.
ai-sn22:2.3.2_0: And then those mendicants approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. They got up from their seats, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.
ai-sn22:2.3.2_1: and after going, they exchanged greetings with him.
ai-sn22:2.3.3_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side.
ai-sn22:2.3.3_1: They told him what had happened, and said,
ai-sn22:2.3.4_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, we wish to go to a western land to take up residence there.
ai-sn22:2.3.5_0: We have consulted with the Teacher.”
ai-sn22:2.4.1_0: “Reverends, there are those who question a mendicant who has gone abroad—
ai-sn22:2.4.2_0: astute aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics—
ai-sn22:2.4.4_0: ‘But what does the venerables’ Teacher teach? What does he explain?’ I trust the venerables have properly heard, learned, attended, and remembered the teachings, and penetrated them with wisdom. That way, when answering you will repeat what the Buddha has said and not misrepresent him with an untruth. You will explain in line with the teaching, with no legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism.
ai-sn22:2.5.1_0: “Reverend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta.
ai-sn22:2.5.2_0: Please explain this matter so it would be good if we were spoken by Sāriputta.”
ai-sn22:2.5.3_0: “Well then, reverends, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn22:2.6.1_0: “Reverends, there are those who question a mendicant who has gone abroad—
ai-sn22:2.6.2_0: astute aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics—
ai-sn22:2.6.4_0: ‘But what does the venerables’ Teacher teach? What does he explain?’
ai-sn22:2.6.6_0: ‘Reverend, our Teacher explained the removal of desire and lust.’
ai-sn22:2.7.2_0: astute aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics—
ai-sn22:2.7.4_0: ‘But regarding what does the venerables’ teacher explain the removal of desire and lust?’
ai-sn22:2.7.6_0: ‘Our teacher explains the removal of desire and lust for form,
ai-sn22:2.7.7_0: When you cling, strongly cling, to desire, greed, relishing, and craving for feeling ...
ai-sn22:2.8.2_0: astute aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics—
ai-sn22:2.8.4_0: ‘But what drawback has he seen that he teaches the removal of desire and lust for form,
ai-sn22:2.8.5_0: When you cling, strongly cling, to desire, greed, relishing, and craving for feeling ...
ai-sn22:2.8.10_0: ‘If you’re not free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes it gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:2.8.11_0: When you cling, strongly cling, to desire, greed, relishing, and craving for feeling ...
ai-sn22:2.8.13_0: When you’re not rid of greed for choices ...
ai-sn22:2.8.14_0: When you’re not rid of craving, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress arise.
ai-sn22:2.8.15_0: consciousness, when that consciousness decays and perishes it gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:2.8.16_0: This is the drawback that we have seen with desire and lust for form,
ai-sn22:2.8.17_0: When you cling, strongly cling, to desire, greed, relishing, and craving for feeling ...
ai-sn22:2.9.2_0: astute aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics—
ai-sn22:2.9.4_0: ‘But what benefit does he see that he teaches the removal of desire and lust for form,
ai-sn22:2.9.5_0: When you cling, strongly cling, to desire, greed, relishing, and craving for feeling ...
ai-sn22:2.9.10_0: ‘If you are rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:2.9.11_0: When you cling, strongly cling, to desire, greed, relishing, and craving for feeling ...
ai-sn22:2.9.13_0: If you are rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for choices don’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:2.9.14_0: consciousness, when that consciousness decays and perishes it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:2.9.15_0: This is the benefit of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
ai-sn22:2.10.1_0: If those who acquired and kept unskillful qualities were to live happily in the present life, free of anguish, distress, and fever; and if, when their body breaks up, after death, they could expect to go to a good place, the Buddha would not praise giving up unskillful qualities.
ai-sn22:2.10.2_0: But since those who acquire and keep unskillful qualities live unhappily in the present life, full of anguish, distress, and fever; and since, when their body breaks up, after death, they can expect to go to a bad place, the Buddha praises giving up unskillful qualities.
ai-sn22:2.11.1_0: If those who embraced and kept skillful qualities were to live unhappily in the present life, full of anguish, distress, and fever; and if, when their body breaks up, after death, they could expect to go to a bad place, the Buddha would not praise embracing skillful qualities.
ai-sn22:2.11.2_0: But since those who embrace and keep skillful qualities live happily in the present life, free of anguish, distress, and fever; and since, when their body breaks up, after death, they can expect to go to a good place, the Buddha praises embracing skillful qualities.”
ai-sn22:2.12.1_0: This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.
ai-sn22:2.12.2_0: and those monks were uplifted and greatly rejoiced in venerable Sāriputta’s words.
ai-sn22:3.1.2_0: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis near Kurararaghara on Steep Mountain.
ai-sn22:3.1.3_0: Then the householder Hāliddikāni went up to Venerable Mahākaccāna,
ai-sn22:3.1.3_1: after approaching and worshipping the venerable Mahākaccāna, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn22:3.1.3_2: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Mahākaccāna:
ai-sn22:3.1.4_0: “Sir, this was said by the Buddha in ‘The Chapter of Māgandiya’:
ai-sn22:3.2.1_0: ‘After leaving shelter to become an unsettled migrant,
ai-sn22:3.2.2_0: a sage doesn’t get close to anyone in town.
ai-sn22:3.3.1_0: How should we see the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement?”
ai-sn22:3.4.1_0: “Householder, the form element is a shelter for consciousness.
ai-sn22:3.4.2_0: One whose consciousness is shackled to greed for the form element is called a migrant going from shelter to shelter.
ai-sn22:3.4.3_0: The feeling element is a shelter for consciousness.
ai-sn22:3.4.4_0: One whose consciousness is attached to greed for the feeling element is called a migrant going from shelter to shelter.
ai-sn22:3.4.5_0: The perception element is a shelter for consciousness.
ai-sn22:3.4.6_0: One whose consciousness is attached to greed for the perception element is called a migrant going from shelter to shelter.
ai-sn22:3.4.7_0: The choices element is a shelter for consciousness.
ai-sn22:3.4.8_0: One whose consciousness is attached to greed for the element is called a migrant going from shelter to shelter.
ai-sn22:3.4.9_0: That’s how one is a migrant going from shelter to shelter.
ai-sn22:3.5.1_0: And how is one a migrant without a shelter?
ai-sn22:3.5.2_0: The Realized One has given up any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for the form element; any attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendencies. He has cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn22:3.5.3_0: That’s why the Realized One is called a migrant going from shelter to shelter.
ai-sn22:3.5.4_0: Consider any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for the feeling element ...
ai-sn22:3.5.7_0: the consciousness element; any attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendencies. He has cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn22:3.5.8_0: That’s why the Realized One is called a migrant going from shelter to shelter.
ai-sn22:3.5.9_0: That’s how one is a migrant without a shelter.
ai-sn22:3.6.1_0: And how is one a migrant going from settlement to settlement?
ai-sn22:3.6.2_0: Being attached to migrating from settlement to settlement in pursuit of sights, one is called a migrant going from settlement to settlement.
ai-sn22:3.6.3_0: Being attached to migrating from settlement to settlement in pursuit of sounds ...
ai-sn22:3.6.7_0: thoughts, one is called a migrant going from settlement to settlement.
ai-sn22:3.6.8_0: That’s how one is a migrant going from settlement to settlement.
ai-sn22:3.7.1_0: And how is one an unsettled migrant?
ai-sn22:3.7.2_0: The Realized One has given up attachment to migrating from settlement to settlement in pursuit of sights. He has cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn22:3.7.3_0: That’s why the Realized One is called an unsettled migrant.
ai-sn22:3.7.4_0: The Realized One has given up attachment to migrating from settlement to settlement in pursuit of sounds ...
ai-sn22:3.7.8_0: thoughts. He has cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn22:3.7.9_0: That’s why the Realized One is called an unsettled migrant.
ai-sn22:3.7.10_0: That’s how one is an unsettled migrant.
ai-sn22:3.8.1_0: And how does one get close to people in town?
ai-sn22:3.8.2_0: It’s when someone mixes closely with laypeople, sharing their joys and sorrows—happy when they’re happy and sad when they’re sad—and getting involved in their business.
ai-sn22:3.8.3_0: That’s how one is born in a village.
ai-sn22:3.9.1_0: And how does one not get close to people in town?
ai-sn22:3.9.2_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t mix closely with laypeople, not sharing their joys and sorrows—not happy when they’re happy or sad when they’re sad—and not getting involved in their business.
ai-sn22:3.9.3_0: That’s how one is not born in a village.
ai-sn22:3.10.1_0: And how is one not rid of sensual pleasures?
ai-sn22:3.10.2_0: It’s when someone isn’t rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.
ai-sn22:3.10.3_0: That’s how one is not rid of sensual pleasures.
ai-sn22:3.11.1_0: And how is one rid of sensual pleasures?
ai-sn22:3.11.2_0: It’s when someone is rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.
ai-sn22:3.11.3_0: That’s how one is rid of sensual pleasures.
ai-sn22:3.12.1_0: And how does one have expectations?
ai-sn22:3.12.3_0: ‘In the future, may I be of such form, such feeling, such perception, such choices, and such consciousness!’
ai-sn22:3.13.1_0: And how does one expect nothing?
ai-sn22:3.13.3_0: ‘In the future, may I be of such form, such feeling, such perception, such choices, and such consciousness!’
ai-sn22:3.13.4_0: That’s how one has no expectations.
ai-sn22:3.14.1_0: And how does one argue with people?
ai-sn22:3.14.2_0: It’s when someone takes part in this sort of discussion:
ai-sn22:3.14.3_0: ‘You don’t understand this teaching and training.
ai-sn22:3.14.3_1: I understand this teaching and training.
ai-sn22:3.14.3_2: I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training?
ai-sn22:3.14.3_8: You said first what you should have said last.
ai-sn22:3.14.3_9: You said first what you should have said last.
ai-sn22:3.14.4_0: That’s how one argues with people.
ai-sn22:3.15.1_0: And how does one not argue with people?
ai-sn22:3.15.2_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t have such a part.
ai-sn22:3.15.3_0: ‘You don’t understand this teaching and training ... get yourself out of this—if you can!’
ai-sn22:3.15.4_0: That’s how one doesn’t argue with people.
ai-sn22:3.16.1_0: So, householder, that’s how to understand the detailed meaning of what the Buddha said in brief in the Chapter of the Eights, in ‘The Questions of Māgandiya’:
ai-sn22:3.17.1_0: ‘After leaving shelter to become an unsettled migrant,
ai-sn22:3.17.2_0: a sage doesn’t get close to anyone in town.
ai-sn22:3.18.1_0: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”
ai-sn22:4.1.2_0: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis near Kurararaghara on Steep Mountain.
ai-sn22:4.1.3_0: Then the householder Hāliddikāni went up to Venerable Mahākaccāna ...
ai-sn22:4.1.3_1: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Mahākaccāna:
ai-sn22:4.1.4_0: “Sir, this was said by the Buddha in ‘The Questions of Sakka’:
ai-sn22:4.1.5_0: ‘Those ascetics and brahmins who are freed due to the ending of craving have reached the ultimate goal, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate end, and are best among gods and humans.’”
ai-sn22:4.2.1_0: How should we see the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement?”
ai-sn22:4.3.1_0: “Householder, consider any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for the form element; any attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendencies. With the ending, fading away, cessation, giving away, and letting go of that, the mind is said to be ‘well freed’.
ai-sn22:4.4.1_0: Consider any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for the feeling element ...
ai-sn22:4.4.4_0: the consciousness element; any attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendencies. With the ending, fading away, cessation, giving away, and letting go of that, the mind is said to be ‘well freed’.
ai-sn22:4.5.1_0: So, householder, that’s how to understand the detailed meaning of what the Buddha said in ‘The Questions of Sakka’:
ai-sn22:4.5.2_0: ‘Those ascetics and brahmins who are freed due to the ending of craving have reached the ultimate goal, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate end, and are best among gods and humans.’”
ai-sn22:4.6.1_0: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”
ai-sn22:5.1.3_0: There they went to see the Buddha ... and asked him,
ai-sn22:5.1.5_0: A mendicant who has immersion truly understands.
ai-sn22:5.1.7_0: The origin and ending of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
ai-sn22:5.2.1_0: And what is the origin of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?
ai-sn22:5.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging.
ai-sn22:5.3.1_0: What do they approve, welcome, and keep clinging to?
ai-sn22:5.3.2_0: They approve, welcome, and keep clinging to form.
ai-sn22:5.3.5_0: Their grasping is a condition for continued existence.
ai-sn22:5.3.7_0: with birth as condition: old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, sorrow, and despair (all) arise,
ai-sn22:5.3.8_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
ai-sn22:5.4.1_0: They approve, welcome, and keep clinging to feeling ...
ai-sn22:5.4.7_0: Their grasping is a condition for continued existence.
ai-sn22:5.4.9_0: Rebirth is a condition that gives rise to old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn22:5.4.10_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
ai-sn22:5.5.1_0: This is the origin of form,

ai-sn22:7.1.2_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you about grasping and grasping.

ai-sn22:7.2.1_0: “And how does grasping lead to anxiety?
ai-sn22:7.2.2_0: It’s when an uneducated ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons.
ai-sn22:7.2.3_0: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
ai-sn22:7.2.4_0: But that form of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:7.2.5_0: and consciousness latches on to the perishing of form.
ai-sn22:7.2.6_0: Anxieties occupy their mind, born of latching on to the perishing of form, and originating in accordance with natural principles.
ai-sn22:7.2.7_0: So they become frightened, worried, concerned, and anxious because of grasping.
ai-sn22:7.3.2_0: But that feeling of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:7.3.3_0: and consciousness latches on to the perishing of feeling.
ai-sn22:7.3.4_0: Anxieties occupy their mind, born of latching on to the perishing of feeling, and originating in accordance with natural principles.
ai-sn22:7.3.5_0: So they become frightened, worried, concerned, and anxious because of grasping.
ai-sn22:7.4.3_0: But their choices decay and perish.
ai-sn22:7.4.4_0: consciousness latches on to the perishing of choices.
ai-sn22:7.4.5_0: Anxieties occupy their mind, born of latching on to the perishing of choices, and originating in accordance with natural principles.
ai-sn22:7.4.6_0: So they become frightened, worried, concerned, and anxious because of grasping.
ai-sn22:7.5.1_0: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
ai-sn22:7.5.2_0: But that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:7.5.3_0: consciousness latches on to the perishing of consciousness.
ai-sn22:7.5.4_0: Anxieties occupy their mind, born of latching on to the perishing of consciousness, and originating in accordance with natural principles.
ai-sn22:7.5.5_0: So they become frightened, worried, concerned, and anxious because of grasping.
ai-sn22:7.5.6_0: That’s how grasping leads to anxiety.
ai-sn22:7.6.1_0: And how does not grasping lead to freedom from anxiety?
ai-sn22:7.6.2_0: It’s when an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons.
ai-sn22:7.6.3_0: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
ai-sn22:7.6.4_0: But that form of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:7.6.5_0: consciousness doesn’t latch on to the perishing of form.
ai-sn22:7.6.6_0: Anxieties—born of latching on to the perishing of form and originating in accordance with natural principles—don’t occupy their mind.
ai-sn22:7.6.7_0: So they don’t become frightened, worried, concerned, or anxious because of grasping.
ai-sn22:7.7.1_0: Doesn’t view feeling as self, or self as endowed with feeling,
ai-sn22:7.7.1_1: or feeling as in self, or self as in feeling.
ai-sn22:7.7.2_0: But that feeling of theirs decays and perishes,
ai-sn22:7.7.3_0: consciousness doesn’t latch on to the perishing of feeling.
ai-sn22:7.7.4_0: Anxieties—born of latching on to the perishing of feeling and originating in accordance with natural principles—don’t occupy their mind.
ai-sn22:7.7.5_0: So they don’t become frightened, worried, concerned, or anxious because of grasping.
ai-sn22:7.8.1_0: They don’t regard perception as self ...
ai-sn22:7.8.2_0: or (volitional) processes as in self, or self as in (volitional) processes.

ai-sn22:7.8.4_0: But their choices decay and perish.
ai-sn22:7.8.5_0: consciousness doesn’t latch on to the perishing of choices.
ai-sn22:7.8.6_0: Anxieties—born of latching on to the perishing of choices and originating in accordance with natural principles—don’t occupy their mind.
ai-sn22:7.8.7_0: So they don’t become frightened, worried, concerned, or anxious because of grasping.

ai-sn22:7.9.4_0: Anxieties—born of latching on to the perishing of consciousness and originating in accordance with natural principles—don’t occupy their mind.
ai-sn22:7.9.5_0: So they don’t become frightened, worried, concerned, or anxious because of grasping.
ai-sn22:7.9.6_0: That’s how not grasping leads to freedom from anxiety.”

ai-sn22:12.1.7_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”

ai-sn22:22.1.2_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the burden, the bearer of the burden, the picking up of the burden, and the putting down of the burden.
ai-sn22:22.1.5_0: It should be said: the five grasping aggregates.
ai-sn22:22.1.7_0: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
ai-sn22:22.2.1_0: And who is the bearer of the burden?
ai-sn22:22.2.2_0: The person, it should be said;
ai-sn22:22.2.3_0: the venerable of such and such name and clan.
ai-sn22:22.2.4_0: This is called the bearer of the burden.
ai-sn22:22.3.1_0: And what is the picking up of the burden?
ai-sn22:22.3.2_0: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure in various different realms. That is,
ai-sn22:22.3.3_0: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continued existence, and craving to end existence.
ai-sn22:22.3.4_0: This is called the picking up of the burden.
ai-sn22:22.4.2_0: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not adhering to it.
ai-sn22:22.5.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn22:22.5.2_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-sn22:22.6.2_0: and the person is the bearer of the burden.

ai-sn22:23.1.2_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that should be completely understood, and complete understanding.
ai-sn22:23.1.4_0: And what things should be completely understood?
ai-sn22:23.1.5_0: Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
ai-sn22:23.1.6_0: These are called the things that should be completely understood.
ai-sn22:23.1.8_0: The ending of greed, hate, and delusion.
ai-sn22:24.1.2_0: “Mendicants, without directly knowing and completely understanding form, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.
ai-sn22:24.1.3_0: Without directly knowing and completely understanding feeling ...
ai-sn22:24.1.5_0: Without directly knowing and completely understanding choices, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.
ai-sn22:24.1.6_0: consciousness, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.
ai-sn22:24.1.7_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding sights ...
ai-sn22:24.1.8_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding feeling ...
ai-sn22:24.1.11_0: consciousness, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.”
ai-sn22:25.1.2_0: “Mendicants, give up desire and greed for form.
ai-sn22:25.1.3_0: Thus that form will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn22:25.1.4_0: Give up desire and greed for feeling ...
ai-sn22:25.1.5_0: Thus that feeling will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn22:25.1.7_0: That perception will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn22:25.1.8_0: Give up desire and greed for choices.
ai-sn22:25.1.9_0: In this way those (volitional) processes will be cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn22:25.1.11_0: Thus that consciousness will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.”
ai-sn22:26.1.2_0: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
ai-sn22:26.1.3_0: ‘What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to form ...
ai-sn22:26.1.4_0: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?
ai-sn22:26.1.6_0: the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to choices?
ai-sn22:26.1.9_0: ‘The pleasure and happiness that arise from form: this is its gratification.
ai-sn22:26.1.10_0: That form is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-sn22:26.1.11_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for form: this is its escape.
ai-sn22:26.1.12_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling ...
ai-sn22:26.1.13_0: That feeling is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-sn22:26.1.14_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape.
ai-sn22:26.1.16_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from choices: this is its gratification.
ai-sn22:26.1.17_0: That choices are impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-sn22:26.1.18_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for choices: this is its escape.
ai-sn22:26.1.20_0: That consciousness is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-sn22:26.1.21_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for consciousness: this is its escape.’
ai-sn22:26.2.1_0: As long as I didn’t truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-sn22:26.2.2_0: But when I did truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-sn22:26.2.3_0: So I used to be a supreme fully awakened Buddha in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-sn22:26.2.4_0: To me knowledge and insight arose:
ai-sn22:26.2.5_0: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

ai-sn22:82.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
ai-sn22:82.1.2_0: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.
ai-sn22:82.2.1_0: Then one of the mendicants got up from their seat, arranged their robe over one shoulder, raised their joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
ai-sn22:82.2.2_0: “I’d like to ask the Buddha about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
ai-sn22:82.2.3_0: “Well then, mendicant, take your own seat and ask what you wish.”
ai-sn22:82.2.4_0: “Yes, sir,” replied that mendicant. He took his seat and said to the Buddha:
ai-sn22:82.2.5_0: “Sir, are these the five grasping aggregates, that is:
ai-sn22:82.2.6_0: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”
ai-sn22:82.3.2_0: That is: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.”
ai-sn22:82.3.3_0: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he asked another question:
ai-sn22:82.4.1_0: “But sir, what is the root of these five grasping aggregates?”
ai-sn22:82.4.2_0: “These five grasping aggregates are rooted in desire.” ...
ai-sn22:82.4.3_0: “But sir, is that grasping the exact same thing as the five grasping aggregates? Or is grasping one thing and the five grasping aggregates another?”
ai-sn22:82.4.4_0: “Neither. Rather, the desire and greed for them is the grasping there.”
ai-sn22:82.4.5_0: Saying “Good, sir,” that mendicant asked another question:
ai-sn22:82.5.1_0: “But sir, can there be different kinds of desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates?”
ai-sn22:82.5.4_0: ‘In the future, may I be of such form, such feeling, such perception, such choices, and such consciousness!’
ai-sn22:82.5.5_0: That’s how there can be different kinds of desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates.”
ai-sn22:82.5.6_0: Saying “Good, sir,” that mendicant asked another question:
ai-sn22:82.6.1_0: “Sir, what is the scope of the term ‘aggregates’ as applied to the aggregates?”
ai-sn22:82.6.2_0: “Any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of form.
ai-sn22:82.6.3_0: Any kind of feeling at all ...
ai-sn22:82.6.5_0: Any kind of choices at all ...
ai-sn22:82.6.6_0: Any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of consciousness.
ai-sn22:82.6.7_0: That’s the scope of the term ‘aggregates’ as applied to the aggregates.”
ai-sn22:82.7.1_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why the aggregate of form is found?
ai-sn22:82.7.2_0: What is the cause, what is the reason why the aggregate of feeling ...
ai-sn22:82.7.3_0: What is the cause, what is the reason why the aggregate of perception,
ai-sn22:82.7.4_0: What is the cause, what is the reason why the aggregate of choices is found?
ai-sn22:82.7.6_0: “The four primary elements are the reason why the aggregate of form is found.
ai-sn22:82.7.7_0: Contact is the reason why the aggregates of feeling ...
ai-sn22:82.7.10_0: Name and form are the reasons why the aggregate of consciousness is found.”
ai-sn22:82.8.1_0: “Sir, how does identity view come about?”
ai-sn22:82.8.2_0: “It’s when an uneducated ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons.
ai-sn22:82.8.3_0: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
ai-sn22:82.8.7_0: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
ai-sn22:82.8.8_0: That’s how identity view comes about.”
ai-sn22:82.9.1_0: “But sir, how does identity view not come about?”
ai-sn22:82.9.2_0: “It’s when an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons.
ai-sn22:82.9.3_0: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
ai-sn22:82.9.4_0: I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to feeling ...
ai-sn22:82.9.6_0: They don’t regard choices as self ...
ai-sn22:82.9.7_0: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness,
ai-sn22:82.9.7_1: or consciousness as in self, or self as in consciousness.
ai-sn22:82.9.8_0: That’s how identity view does not come about.”
ai-sn22:82.10.1_0: “Sir, what’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to form,
ai-sn22:82.10.6_0: “The pleasure and happiness that arise from form: this is its gratification.
ai-sn22:82.10.7_0: That form is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-sn22:82.10.8_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for form: this is its escape.
ai-sn22:82.10.9_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling ...
ai-sn22:82.10.11_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from choices.
ai-sn22:82.10.13_0: That consciousness is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

ai-sn22:103.1.3_0: What are the teachings grouped by four?
ai-sn22:103.1.4_0: The side of identity, the side of the origin of identity, the side of the cessation of identity, and the side of the practice that leads to the cessation of identity.
ai-sn22:103.1.5_0: And what is the side of identity?
ai-sn22:103.1.6_0: It should be said: the five grasping aggregates.
ai-sn22:103.1.8_0: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
ai-sn22:103.1.9_0: This is called the side of identity.
ai-sn22:103.2.1_0: And what is the side of the origin of identity?
ai-sn22:103.2.2_0: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure in various different realms. That is,
ai-sn22:103.2.3_0: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continued existence, and craving to end existence.
ai-sn22:103.2.4_0: This is called the side of the origin of identity.
ai-sn22:103.3.1_0: And what is the side of the cessation of identity?
ai-sn22:103.3.2_0: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not adhering to it.
ai-sn22:103.3.3_0: This is called the side of the cessation of identity.
ai-sn22:103.4.1_0: And what is the side of the practice that leads to the cessation of identity?
ai-sn22:103.4.2_0: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
ai-sn22:103.4.3_0: that is: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
ai-sn22:103.4.4_0: This is called the side of the practice that leads to the cessation of identity.

ai-sn22:104.1.9_0: And what is the origin of suffering?

ai-sn22:104.1.12_0: And what is the cessation of suffering?

ai-sn22:104.1.14_0: This is called the cessation of suffering.

ai-sn22:104.1.18_0: This is called the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.”

ai-sn22:110.1.2_0: “Mendicants, there are these five grasping aggregates.
ai-sn22:110.1.4_0: That is: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
ai-sn22:110.1.5_0: A mendicant comes to be freed by not grasping after truly understanding these five grasping aggregates’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
ai-sn22:110.1.6_0: Such a mendicant is called a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.”

ai-sn22:112.1.9_0: Thus that consciousness will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.”

ai-sn22:117.1.4_0: They’re called an uneducated ordinary person who is bound to form, inside and out. They see neither the near shore nor the far shore. They’re born in bonds and die in bonds, and in bonds they go from this world to the next.

ai-sn22:122.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana. ...
ai-sn22:122.1.2_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of retreat, went to Venerable Sāriputta, bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-sn22:122.1.3_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, what things should an ethical mendicant properly attend to?”
ai-sn22:122.1.4_0: “Reverend Koṭṭhita, an ethical mendicant should properly attend to the five grasping aggregates as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as an abscess, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self.
ai-sn22:122.1.6_0: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
ai-sn22:122.1.7_0: An ethical mendicant should properly attend to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as an abscess, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self.
ai-sn22:122.1.8_0: It’s possible that an ethical mendicant who regards the five grasping aggregates in this way. ...
ai-sn22:122.1.8_1: When you attend properly to the fruit of stream-entry, they’ll realize the fruit of stream-entry.”
ai-sn22:122.2.1_0: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a mendicant stream-enterer properly attend to?”
ai-sn22:122.2.2_0: “A mendicant stream-enterer should meditate observing impermanence in these five grasping aggregates. ...
ai-sn22:122.2.3_0: It’s possible that a mendicant stream-enterer who regards the five grasping aggregates in this way. ...
ai-sn22:122.2.3_1: When you attend properly on the fruit of non-return, they’ll realize the fruit of once-return.”
ai-sn22:122.3.1_0: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a mendicant once-returner properly attend to?”
ai-sn22:122.3.2_0: “A mendicant once-returner should see these five grasping aggregates as impermanent ...
ai-sn22:122.3.3_0: It’s possible that a mendicant once-returner who regards the five grasping aggregates are impermanent ...
ai-sn22:122.3.3_1: When you attend properly, they realize the fruit of non-return.”
ai-sn22:122.4.1_0: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a mendicant non-returner properly attend to?”
ai-sn22:122.4.2_0: “A mendicant non-returner should truly see these five grasping aggregates as impermanent ...
ai-sn22:122.4.3_0: It’s possible that a mendicant who regards the five grasping aggregates in this way. ...
ai-sn22:122.4.3_1: When you attend properly on the not-self, you can realize perfection.”
ai-sn22:122.5.1_0: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a perfected one properly attend to?”
ai-sn22:122.5.2_0: “Reverend Koṭṭhita, a perfected one should properly attend to the five grasping aggregates as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as an abscess, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self.
ai-sn22:122.5.3_0: A perfected one has nothing more to do, and nothing that needs improvement.
ai-sn22:122.5.4_0: Still, these things, when developed and cultivated, lead to blissful meditation in the present life, and also to mindfulness and situational awareness.”

ai-sn22:124.1.2_0: Then Venerable Kappa went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-sn22:124.1.2_1: Seated to one side, Venerable Kappa said to the Buddha:
ai-sn22:124.1.3_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that there’s no ego, possessiveness, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and all external stimuli?”
